questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of VACTERL syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Coloboma of the iris is not a feature of VACTERL association; it is characteristic of CHARGE syndrome.

  • VACTERL association refers to a recognized group of congenital anomalies that tend to occur together without a single identifiable genetic mutation.
  • The acronym stands for:
    • V: Vertebral anomalies
    • A: Anal atresia (Option D ruled out)
    • C: Cardiac defects
    • T: Tracheoesophageal fistula (Option B ruled out)
    • E: Esophageal atresia (Option C ruled out)
    • R: Renal anomalies
    • L: Limb anomalies (usually radial dysplasia)
  • A diagnosis of VACTERL association typically requires at least 3 of these anomalies.
  • Coloboma, a defect in the iris or retina, is not part of this association.
  • Instead, it is a cardinal feature of CHARGE syndrome, which includes Coloboma, Heart defects, Atresia of choanae, Retardation of growth/development, Genital anomalies, and Ear abnormalities.

questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress and frothing from the mouth on Day 1 of life. The baby is cyanosed. What could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Frothing from the mouth with respiratory distress and cyanosis on Day 1 strongly suggests esophageal atresia with/without tracheoesophageal fistula.

  • Esophageal atresia (EA), commonly associated with tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF), is a congenital anomaly where the upper esophagus ends in a blind pouch and may have an abnormal connection with the trachea.
  • In neonates, this presents within the first few hours of life as:
    • Frothing/salivation from the mouth
    • Coughing/choking with feeds
    • Cyanosis
    • Respiratory distress, due to aspiration of secretions or regurgitated milk into the lungs
  • The presence of copious oral secretions and inability to pass a nasogastric tube into the stomach are classic signs.
  • Chest X-ray often shows a coiled NG tube in the upper pouch and air in the stomach (if a fistula is present).

Explanation of other options:

Lung hypoplasia (Option A): Usually associated with oligohydramnios or congenital anomalies like Potter sequence; presents with severe respiratory failure but not frothing.

Congenital lung cyst (Option B): May cause respiratory distress depending on size/location, but frothing from the mouth is not a typical feature.

Diaphragmatic hernia (Option D): Causes respiratory distress due to lung compression, but presents with scaphoid abdomen and displaced heart sounds, not oral frothing.

choices.text: Symptoms develop beyond 48 hr of birth
CDH detected in the 1st trimester scan prenatally

questions.text: A full-term newborn is diagnosed with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). The baby has mild respiratory distress but remains hemodynamically stable. Symptoms only began appearing after 48 hours of birth. Which of the following features is most associated with a good prognosis in such cases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Delayed onset of symptoms beyond 48 hours indicates less severe pulmonary hypoplasia, correlating with a better prognosis.

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a defect in the diaphragm that allows abdominal organs to herniate into the thoracic cavity, leading to pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension, which are the primary determinants of morbidity and mortality.
  • Prognostic factors are critical for parental counseling and clinical management.
  • Among these:
    • Early-onset symptoms (within hours of birth) often indicate severe pulmonary compromise.
    • Conversely, onset of symptoms beyond 24-48 hours suggests better-developed lungs and less severe pulmonary hypoplasia, associated with a favorable prognosis.
  • Other factors that worsen prognosis include liver herniation, low lung-to-head ratio, and early prenatal diagnosis (especially in the first trimester), which are often markers of severe disease.

Explanation of other options:

Lung head ratio <1 (Option A): A low lung-to-head ratio (<1) on prenatal ultrasound indicates severe pulmonary hypoplasia and correlates with poor prognosis.

CDH detected in the 1st trimester scan prenatally (Option C): Very early detection implies severe defect, often with significant herniation and lung compromise, thus a worse prognosis.

Liver herniated into thorax (Option D): Intrathoracic herniation of liver is a poor prognostic marker, as it indicates a large diaphragmatic defect and more severe pulmonary hypoplasia.

choices.text: The infant most likely has an H-type TEF.
The infant most likely has proximal esophageal atresia with distal fistula.
The infant likely has a previously undetected, associated finding of imperforate anus.
The infant is unlikely to have gastroesophageal reflux.

questions.text: An infant with a history of recurrent pneumonia is diagnosed with TEF at 8 months of age. Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Delayed diagnosis of TEF with recurrent pneumonia and feeding-related symptoms is typical of H-type tracheoesophageal fistula, which lacks esophageal atresia.

  • H-type TEF is a rare subtype of tracheoesophageal fistula where the esophagus is intact (no atresia), but there is a fistulous connection between the trachea and the esophagus.
  • Because the esophagus is continuous, infants can feed, and overt symptoms may be milder or delayed, such as chronic cough, recurrent aspiration pneumonia, feeding difficulties, or failure to thrive.
  • This contrasts with the more common types of TEF that present in the neonatal period with inability to feed and copious oral secretions.
  • H-type TEF often escapes early detection and is diagnosed later in infancy or early childhood, typically during workup for recurrent chest infections.

Explanation of other options:

The infant most likely has proximal esophageal atresia with distal fistula (Option B): This is the most common type of TEF but presents within the first few days of life with feeding difficulty, drooling, and inability to pass a nasogastric tube-not at 8 months.

The infant likely has a previously undetected, associated finding of imperforate anus (Option C): Imperforate anus is usually detected immediately after birth, and while it's part of the VACTERL association, it would not explain delayed TEF diagnosis.

The infant is unlikely to have gastroesophageal reflux (Option D): Gastroesophageal reflux (GER) is common in TEF/EA survivors and especially in cases of repaired or longstanding fistulas due to motility disorders or abnormal anatomy.

questions.text: You are called to the nursery to assess a newborn girl. She was born at 39 weeks via normal spontaneous delivery to a mother who had no prenatal care. APGAR scores are 7 and 9. At four hours of life, the nurse noted respiratory distress. On physical examination, her heart rate is 150 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 70 cycles per minute, temperature is 37.1 °C, with a barrel-shaped chest, a scaphoid-appearing abdomen, and absence of breath sounds on the left chest. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A scaphoid abdomen with respiratory distress and absent breath sounds on one side suggests congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), most commonly left-sided (Bochdalek type), results from a defect in the diaphragm that allows abdominal organs (intestines, stomach, liver) to herniate into the thoracic cavity.
  • This leads to:
    • Compression of developing lungs → Pulmonary hypoplasia
    • Mediastinal shift
    • Severe respiratory distress shortly after birth
  • Typical physical signs include:
    • Scaphoid abdomen (due to abdominal contents being in the thorax)
    • Barrel-shaped chest (from lung hyperexpansion on the opposite side)
    • Decreased/absent breath sounds on the affected side
    • Displaced heart sounds
  • CDH is a pediatric emergency and often requires immediate intubation and surgical repair after stabilization.

Explanation of other options:

Congenital lobar emphysema (Option B): Can cause localized overinflation and respiratory distress but typically shows hyperresonant lung fields and no scaphoid abdomen; more gradual in onset.

Meconium aspiration syndrome (Option C): Typically occurs in post-term infants with meconium-stained amniotic fluid and presents with coarse breath sounds and patchy infiltrates-not a scaphoid abdomen.

Respiratory distress syndrome (Option D): Seen in preterm infants, due to surfactant deficiency; findings include grunting, nasal flaring, and ground-glass appearance on X-ray, without the abdominal/thoracic signs described here.

choices.text: Immediate surgical repair of the diaphragmatic defect
Insertion of an intercostal chest tube on the left side
Placement of a nasogastric/orogastric tube with continuous suction

questions.text: A 15-day-old male infant is brought to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress. The child had received bag and mask ventilation en route and is now intubated. On examination, the infant has tachycardia, poor air entry on the left side, and a scaphoid abdomen. Chest X-ray reveals bowel gas shadows in the left hemithorax with rightward mediastinal shift. What is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gastrointestinal decompression via nasogastric/orogastric tube is the critical first step to relieve lung compression in CDH before surgery.

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a life-threatening condition caused by a defect in the diaphragm, most commonly the left posterolateral (Bochdalek) foramen, allowing abdominal contents to herniate into the thoracic cavity.
  • This results in pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension, which are the primary determinants of morbidity and mortality.
  • In a neonate presenting with respiratory distress, scaphoid abdomen, mediastinal shift, and absent breath sounds on the affected side, CDH is strongly suspected.
  • The initial management focuses on stabilization before surgery:

Stepwise Management of Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia:

  • Avoid Bag-Mask Ventilation
    • It can inflate the herniated bowel and worsen respiratory compromise.
  • Immediate Endotracheal Intubation
    • Provides controlled ventilation and prevents air insufflation into the stomach.
  • Insert Nasogastric/Orogastric Tube with Continuous Suction
    • Essential first step to decompress stomach and intestines, relieving pressure on the lungs.
  • Supportive Care
    • IV fluids
    • Thermoregulation
    • Monitor blood gases and oxygenation
  • Gentle Mechanical Ventilation
    • Avoid high peak pressures to prevent barotrauma to hypoplastic lungs.
  • Pulmonary Hypertension Management
    • Use inhaled nitric oxide (iNO), sildenafil, or prostaglandins as needed.
  • High-Frequency Oscillatory Ventilation (HFOV)
    • Consider if conventional ventilation fails.
  • Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO)
    • For severe cases unresponsive to maximal ventilatory and inotropic support.
  • Surgical Repair
    • Only after full stabilization-usually delayed 24-48 hours or longer, depending on clinical condition.
    • Surgery involves returning herniated contents and repairing the diaphragm (with or without a patch).
  • Postoperative Care
    • Continued respiratory support
    • Nutrition via the parenteral route initially
    • Monitor for complications (GER, pulmonary hypertension, neurodevelopmental delays)

Explanation of other options:

Immediate surgical repair (Option A): Surgery should be done only after hemodynamic and respiratory stabilization; rushing into surgery increases the risk of mortality.

Intercostal chest tube (Option B): Contraindicated unless there is coexisting pneumothorax. Inserting it blindly may damage herniated bowel loops.

Bronchoscopy (Option C): Not indicated in the initial emergency setting; may be used later in case of suspected airway anomaly or persistent symptoms.

questions.text: A neonate was diagnosed as a case of trachea-esophageal fistula with esophageal atresia and was posted for surgery next week. As an intern working in the department, you notice certain pre-operative monitoring and management being done. All of the following are allowed to be performed in a pre-operative case of TEF except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Routine intubation is not recommended preoperatively in TEF unless there is respiratory failure; it may worsen pulmonary complications due to air passage into the fistula.

  • Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) with esophageal atresia (EA) is a neonatal emergency requiring early surgical correction.
  • Until surgery is performed, pre-operative stabilization is critical to prevent aspiration, respiratory distress, and sepsis.
  • Most commonly, the infant has proximal esophageal atresia with distal TEF, resulting in accumulation of secretions in the upper pouch and risk of air entering the stomach via the fistula.

Pre-operative Management of TEF/EA:

  • Avoid Oral Feeds:
    • To prevent aspiration of pooled secretions and regurgitated contents.
  • Frequent Upper Pouch Suctioning: (Option A ruled out)
    • Repeated suctioning of the upper esophageal pouch helps prevent aspiration of saliva.
  • Maintain Infant in Semi-upright or Prone Position: (Option B ruled out)
    • Head elevation or prone positioning helps secretions drain away from the lungs, decreasing aspiration risk.
  • Nasogastric Tube into Upper Pouch:
    • It may be used to keep the pouch decompressed (though in EA, it won't pass into the stomach).
  • Use of Broad-Spectrum Prophylactic Antibiotics: (Option D ruled out)
    • Prevents aspiration pneumonia, especially in cases already suspected to have microaspiration.
  • Avoid Routine Endotracheal Intubation:
    • Intubation is avoided unless respiratory failure is present.
    • Why? Because positive-pressure ventilation may drive air through the fistula into the stomach, causing gastric distension → elevation of the diaphragm → worsened respiratory compromise, and risk of gastric rupture.
    • If necessary, gentle ventilation and gastric decompression should be done simultaneously.
  • IV Fluids and Thermoregulation:
    • To maintain hydration and prevent hypothermia.
  • Monitoring for Aspiration Pneumonitis:
    • Respiratory symptoms and chest X-ray findings should be monitored closely.
  • Surgical Timing:
    • Surgery is typically scheduled after stabilization, usually within a few days of birth, depending on the baby's condition.

choices.text: Assess the abdomen to evaluate for possible congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
Perform a needle thoracostomy for possible pneumothorax.
Prepare the infant for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)

questions.text: A term baby is born to a 30-year-old woman who had little prenatal care. Immediately after birth, he has cyanosis and respiratory distress. Chest auscultation in the delivery room reveals right-sided heart sounds and absent left-sided breath sounds. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A scaphoid (sunken) abdomen strongly suggests congenital diaphragmatic hernia, and immediate bedside abdominal assessment is critical for rapid diagnosis.

  • This infant presents with severe respiratory distress and absent breath sounds on the left side, along with displaced heart sounds-a clinical picture highly suggestive of left-sided congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • In CDH, abdominal contents herniate into the thoracic cavity, compressing the lung and causing pulmonary hypoplasia, mediastinal shift, and hypoxia.
  • In such cases, a quick and reliable clinical step is to assess the abdomen:
    • If the abdomen is scaphoid, it supports the diagnosis of CDH, because the abdominal contents (bowel, stomach, sometimes liver) are herniated into the thoracic cavity.
  • Prompt recognition is essential because interventions like bag-mask ventilation or thoracostomy without proper diagnosis can be harmful.

Key Points in Immediate CDH Evaluation:

  • Absent breath sounds on one side + displaced heart sounds + scaphoid abdomen = CDH until proven otherwise
  • Bedside abdominal examination is quick, non-invasive, and critical
  • Chest X-ray confirms diagnosis (bowel loops in chest, mediastinal shift)
  • Avoid bag-mask ventilation to prevent air from entering the gut
  • Immediate intubation and gastric decompression are preferred

Explanation of other options:

Order ultrasonography of the chest (Option B): While ultrasound can support diagnosis, bedside physical assessment is faster and more appropriate as the initial step in an unstable newborn.

Perform a needle thoracostomy for possible pneumothorax (Option C): Incorrect and potentially dangerous-if this is CDH, inserting a needle may puncture herniated bowel, causing perforation and worsening condition.

Prepare the infant for ECMO (Option D): ECMO is used in severe, refractory CDH cases only after diagnosis and stabilization; not the first step.

choices.text: Suctioning of secretions and prone position nursing are needed
Endotracheal intubation is needed in most cases

questions.text: A neonate presented with progressive respiratory distress soon after birth, with extensive frothy secretions drooling from the mouth and abdominal distension. Which among the following is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Endotracheal intubation is not routinely required in all cases of tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF); many cases are managed with suctioning and surgery without intubation unless respiratory compromise is severe.

  • This is a classic presentation of tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) with esophageal atresia, where the upper esophageal pouch ends blindly, and the lower segment is connected to the trachea.
  • Frothy secretions, respiratory distress, and abdominal distension (due to air entering the stomach from the trachea via the fistula) are key features.
  • The first-line management includes:
    • Withholding oral feeds immediately
    • Frequent suctioning of oral secretions via a Replogle tube
    • Prone or semi-upright positioning to reduce the risk of aspiration (Option B ruled out)
    • Oxygen and supportive care; endotracheal intubation is only indicated if severe respiratory distress or apnea is present, not in all cases
  • Surgical correction is definitive and should be done as early as possible, typically after stabilization. (Option D ruled out)
  • Also, TEF is commonly associated with VACTERL association: (Option A ruled out)
    • Vertebral anomalies
    • Anal atresia
    • Cardiac defects
    • Tracheo-Esophageal fistula
    • Renal anomalies
    • Limb abnormalities
  • Summary of Initial Management of TEF:
    • Keep infant NPO (nil per os)
    • Place a Replogle tube for continuous suction in the upper pouch
    • Position prone or semi-upright
    • Endotracheal intubation only if severe respiratory compromise
    • Start IV fluids and antibiotics if risk of aspiration pneumonitis
    • Plan for early surgical repair

questions.text: Involvement of which of the following is responsible for most cases of Bochdalek's hernia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bochdalek's hernia results from a defect in the posterolateral portion of the diaphragm, as shown by label C.

  • Bochdalek's hernia is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) and results from the failure of closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal during embryogenesis, especially on the posterolateral aspect of the diaphragm.
  • This defect is more common on the left side, which anatomically corresponds to the area labeled C in the axial diagram.
  • This area, the posterolateral diaphragm, normally closes by the 8th week of gestation.
  • Failure of this closure allows abdominal contents-such as the stomach, intestines, and sometimes the liver-to herniate into the thoracic cavity, compressing the developing lungs, leading to pulmonary hypoplasia, which is the primary determinant of morbidity and mortality.

Explanation of other options:

A (Option A): Anterior part of the diaphragm - corresponds to Morgagni's hernia, not Bochdalek's.

B (Option B): Lateral diaphragm - not typically the site of embryologic defect causing Bochdalek's hernia.

D (Option D): Posterior mediastinum/spinal region - not part of the diaphragm, hence unrelated to the diaphragmatic defect.

questions.text: The following fetal procedure is performed for which of the following lesions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows fetal endoscopic tracheal occlusion (FETO), a procedure done in severe congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) to promote lung growth.

  • The image illustrates Fetal Endoscopic Tracheal Occlusion (FETO) - a prenatal intervention used in fetuses with severe congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • CDH leads to pulmonary hypoplasia due to herniation of abdominal organs into the thoracic cavity.
  • This reduces lung volume and impairs development.
  • FETO involves inserting a fetoscope via the fetal mouth into the trachea under ultrasound guidance.
  • A balloon is inflated in the trachea (Step 2) to occlude it.
  • The trapped lung fluid cannot escape, causing lung expansion and stimulating lung growth.
  • This balloon is later deflated and removed (Step 3) before delivery.
  • This intervention is used only in severely isolated CDH with poor lung-to-head ratio (LHR) and high mortality risk, as it improves survival in selected cases.

Complete Management of Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia:

  • Antenatal Management:
    • Diagnosis: Typically made on anomaly scan at 18-22 weeks. Look for stomach/chest bubbles, mediastinal shift.
    • Prognosis Assessment: Lung-to-head ratio (LHR), liver herniation, and total fetal lung volume on MRI.
    • FETO procedure: Done for severe isolated left-sided CDH with low LHR to stimulate lung growth.
    • Delivery planning: At a tertiary care center with neonatal intensive care and pediatric surgery.
  • Postnatal Management:
    • Initial stabilization:
      • Avoid bag-mask ventilation (risk of bowel distension).
      • Intubate immediately; start gentle ventilation with permissive hypercapnia.
      • Maintain preductal SpO2 of 85-95%.
      • Use of high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV) and inhaled nitric oxide (iNO) if pulmonary hypertension is severe.
      • ECMO (extracorporeal membrane oxygenation) may be needed in extreme cases.
    • Surgical repair:
      • Delayed until cardiorespiratory stabilization is achieved.
      • Approach: Open or minimally invasive.
      • Repair of diaphragmatic defects with/without a patch.
    • Long-term follow-up:
      • Monitor for pulmonary complications, GERD, growth delay, and neurodevelopmental issues.

Explanation of other options:

Tracheo-esophageal fistula (Option A): Repaired surgically after birth; prenatal intervention is not standard. No tracheal occlusion required.

Choanal atresia (Option C): A postnatal nasal airway obstruction; treated by surgical repair after delivery. FETO is not indicated.

Laryngomalacia (Option D): A common cause of stridor in infants; managed conservatively or with supraglottoplasty postnatally. FETO is not useful.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common variety of TEF?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Type C TEF (esophageal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula) is the most common type, accounting for approximately 85% of cases.

  • Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) refers to an abnormal communication between the trachea and esophagus.
  • It often coexists with esophageal atresia (EA).
  • Based on the Gross classification, TEF is divided into several types (A-E), and among these, Type C is by far the most common:
    • Type C (85%)
    • Esophageal atresia with distal TEF
    • The upper esophageal segment ends blindly.
    • The lower segment forms a fistulous connection with the trachea.
    • Clinical presentation: Frothing and bubbling at the mouth, choking, coughing, cyanosis on feeding, and inability to pass a nasogastric tube.

Explanation of other options:

Type A (Option A): Esophageal atresia without any fistula (pure EA). Accounts for ~8%. No gas in the abdomen (since there's no fistula to allow air into the GI tract).

Type B (Option B): Esophageal atresia with proximal TEF (very rare, <1%). Gasless abdomen. Difficult to diagnose without imaging.

Type D (Option D): Esophageal atresia with both proximal and distal TEF. Extremely rare (<1%). Complex anatomy, difficult to manage surgically.

questions.text: A neonate who underwent surgical repair for congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is now being followed up in the pediatric surgery outpatient clinic. The child presents with occasional vomiting and poor weight gain. As part of routine surveillance, the team assesses for possible complications known in CDH survivors. All of the following are common complications in survivors of CDH, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hepatic fibrosis is not a recognized or common complication in CDH survivors, whereas GERD, recurrence, and intestinal obstruction are.

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a developmental defect in the diaphragm that allows abdominal organs to herniate into the thoracic cavity, leading to pulmonary hypoplasia and other complications.
  • Following surgical repair and neonatal intensive care, long-term follow-up is essential due to the risk of several complications.

Common complications in CDH survivors include:

  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): (Option B ruled out)
    • Occurs due to intra-abdominal pressure changes, abnormal esophageal motility, and disruption of the gastroesophageal junction.
    • May lead to feeding difficulties, aspiration, and poor weight gain.
  • Recurrence of CDH: (Option C ruled out)
    • Especially seen in cases repaired using patches or with tension during primary closure.
    • Can present with respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Intestinal obstruction: (Option D ruled out)
    • Adhesions after surgery can cause mechanical obstruction.
    • Can present with vomiting, abdominal distension, and failure to pass stools.
  • Pulmonary complications:
    • Chronic lung disease, pulmonary hypertension, and recurrent infections due to pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • Neurodevelopmental delays:
    • Due to prolonged NICU stay, hypoxia, and other morbidities.
  • However, hepatic fibrosis is not a recognized complication directly associated with CDH or its repair. Liver herniation through the diaphragm may occur (especially in right-sided CDH), but it does not typically result in hepatic fibrosis.

choices.text: X-ray after passing a nasogastric tube

questions.text: A full-term newborn presents within hours of birth with excessive salivation, choking, and episodes of cyanosis during attempted feeding. The attending pediatrician suspects esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). Which of the following is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis of esophageal atresia with suspected tracheoesophageal fistula in this neonate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Passing a nasogastric tube followed by an X-ray shows coiling of the tube in the upper esophageal pouch, confirming esophageal atresia.

  • Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (EA/TEF) is a common congenital anomaly where the upper and lower esophageal segments are disconnected, and the lower segment typically communicates with the trachea.
  • Clinically, it presents with drooling, choking, coughing, and cyanosis during feeding.
  • The investigation of choice is to gently pass a nasogastric (NG) tube (usually size 10 Fr) and take a chest and abdominal X-ray.
  • In cases of esophageal atresia, the tube typically coils in the upper pouch, and air is seen in the stomach and intestines if a distal TEF is present.
  • This method is safe, quick, non-invasive, and avoids the risk of aspiration that can occur with barium studies.

Explanation of other options:

CECT (Option A): Not used for initial diagnosis. It may be used later in complicated or unclear cases or for surgical planning.

Barium Swallow (Option B): Contraindicated in suspected EA/TEF due to risk of aspiration and chemical pneumonitis.

USG Abdomen (Option C): Not diagnostic for EA/TEF. May be used to assess associated anomalies (e.g., renal) in VACTERL association.
